column1: He also promised to do what was necessary to safeguard public confidence in the system. "We want to be fair to the public, to make sure people understand why we do what we do," he told parliament on Wednesday. "When you look at it from a public point of view, there needs to be some balance between the public's confidence in the system and the public's confidence in the process." He said he did not believe the government was "disingenuous" in its approach to the system. The government would not commit to legislating without Mr Johnson's approval. The Commons committee said it would publish the evidence on Friday and there was no time to amend the report before the Commons floor. It said it would review the findings before publishing their final report. Mr Johnson's team said in a statement: "He is pleased to be standing in the House of Commons and he has made clear that he does not intend to resign from office. He was asked to do so at his request but was not given the chance to do so." The report is due to be published on Thursday, but would not be subject to the public's approval. The committee's leader, Lord Greenhalgh, said: "The committee will need to review what has been submitted in the interests of making appropriate redactions to protect the identity of some witnesses. The committee will be scrutinising all the evidence and will also be looking at whether it is reckless or intentional. The committee will then have to decide whether to grant a sanction and how it should be punished. There are some questions that need to be answered. The process of approval and sanction procedures at the moment is very different from the process of approval and sanction. We want to get on with our work without fear or favour. The government will not commit to legislating without Mr Johnson's approval." Mr Johnson has said the issue of what he is allowed to do in a private home is "not a big issue" on his personal life. "I've done all I can to keep my house clean and I've cleaned my house. I've had to clean my house to be able to get on with my life," he told ITV's The World at One programme.
